translated: 2 YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra, fascicle 66
Spoken by Maitreya Bodhisattva
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order
In the chapter on the stage of wisdom attained through contemplation, part two. Next, as the World-Honored Buddha has said, there are three kinds of suffering.
What is the nature of suffering due to conditioned existence in this context?

It refers to the conditioned activities produced by karma and afflictions in subsequent existences.ğŸ”½They are able to follow and give rise to all afflictions and various kinds of suffering, and establish them.
All pervasive coarse and heavy afflictions are included.
They are also called coarse and heavy.
This is the nature of suffering due to conditioned existence.
Based on this suffering due to conditioned existence,
the World-Honored Buddha has said that the five appropriated aggregates in brief are all called suffering.
Moreover, this suffering due to conditioned existence pervades all, whether in pleasant feelings, painful feelings, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings.
However, in neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings,
the nature of coarse and heavy afflictions is clearly manifested.
Therefore, it is said that only the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is suffering due to the suffering of conditioned existence.
In pleasant feelings and painful feelings,
Because the two dharmas of love and hatred disturb the mind.
This suffering of coarseness and heaviness is not easy to understand.
It is like a hot boil.
If it is covered with a cold touch, one imagines it to be pleasant.
If hot ashes fall on it, one imagines it to be painful.
If one is free from both,
at that time, in this hot boil, only the part of suffering that is the inherent nature of the boil is clearly manifest.
In the same way, in the various practices produced by karma and afflictions,
all that is included in the establishment of coarseness and heaviness
is like a hot boil.
In the nature of the suffering of conditioned existence, pleasant feeling is like a cold touch covering it.
Painful feeling is like hot ashes falling on it.
Neutral feeling is like the inherent suffering of the boil when free from both touches.
Moreover, in pleasant feeling, attachment is often produced.
Therefore, it is said that it increases with craving.
In painful feeling, aversion is often produced.
Therefore, it is said that it increases with hatred.
In the body of practices established in the manifest coarseness subsumed within neither-painful-nor-pleasant,
in regard to the nature of impermanence, there is the perversion of permanence.
In regard to the nature of various sufferings, there is the perversion of happiness.
In regard to the nature of impurity, there is the perversion of purity.
In regard to the nature of non-self, there is the perversion of self.
Therefore, it is said that in the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, ignorance increases.
Moreover, the foolish in regard to pleasant feeling often give rise to attachment.
Because of this cause and condition,
in the present life, they engage in bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct.
When the body perishes and life ends, it is said that they are born in the hells.
Moreover, because of craving for future existence, they are able to attract the various sufferings of future birth and so forth.
In this way, pleasant feeling, because it is the basis for craving, is able to give rise to the suffering of the five destinies and so forth in the future.
Moreover, in regard to painful feeling, one often gives rise to anger.
Not being able to touch the various painful things as one wishes,
one then gives rise to various kinds of sorrow, lamentation, and even confusion.
Because of this, one engages in the three kinds of evil conduct and falls into the evil destinies.
In this way, painful feelings are the basis for anger.
They can lead to the suffering of the present life and future lives.
Moreover, in the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant, one often gives rise to the above kinds of inverted thoughts.
Regarding the two kinds of suffering,
that is, the suffering produced by craving based on the feeling of pleasure,
and the suffering produced by anger based on the feeling of pain,
one gives rise to thoughts of non-abandonment and engages in non-abandonment.
Therefore, although there are many afflictions and secondary afflictions,
the World-Honored Buddha only established three fundamental afflictions,
namely, craving, anger, and delusion.
Based on this secret meaning, the World-Honored Buddha said:
One should contemplate that the feeling of pleasure is a dharma of various sufferings.
One should contemplate that the feeling of pain is like a poisonous arrow.
One should contemplate that the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant is by nature impermanent and subject to destruction.
If one can contemplate the nature of impermanence as it really is,
one will gradually be able to eliminate all inversions.
These formations are the first truth of suffering.
All sages and saints, having contemplated with their wisdom,
In the most tranquil aggregates of grasping in the highest existence,
Still do not delight in them,
How much less so in the inferior hells.
Furthermore, these formations that give rise to subsequent existence, whether karma or afflictions,
By their characteristic principle are the truth of the origin.
The World-Honored One, in the sÅ«tras, based on the superior principle, only reveals craving.
Furthermore, the permanent cessation of the coarseness of this class of afflictions,
Is the truth of cessation established by the supremacy of nirvÄá¹‡a with remainder.
Also, due to the permanent severance of the cause, future non-arising,
And the exhaustion of the enjoyment of past causes,
The present formations naturally cease.
This is the truth of cessation established by the supremacy of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder.
Furthermore, the right view that realizes the ultimate truth,
And all the holy paths preceded by right view,
This is called the truth of the path.
Furthermore, in order to thoroughly know suffering, to permanently eliminate its origin,
to realize its cessation, and to cultivate the path,
the characteristics of the noble truths are established in brief.
If they were established in detail, their characteristics would be known to be immeasurable and boundless.
Moreover, in order to make one understand the coarse characteristics of the truth of suffering as a basis,
one is gradually able to enter the subtle characteristics of the truth.
Therefore, the various sufferings such as birth are established first,
and only then the suffering of the five appropriated aggregates is revealed.
Furthermore, the distinctions of the dharmas that are upheld are established by means of five aspects.
What are the five?ğŸ”½First, food by mouthfuls.
Second, food by contact.
Third, food by intention.
Fourth, food by consciousness.
Fifth, the faculty of life. If coarse food by mouthfuls,
it is all presently found in the five destinies of the desire realm.
This is in a part of the individual hells,
not in the great hells.
The other foods and life,
are all presently found throughout the three realms.
Because sentient beings are provisionally established in relation to the various conditioned factors.
Therefore, the World-Honored One says that these dharmas sustain sentient beings, causing them to abide without destruction.
Question: There are seven causes and conditions that sustain conditioned forces, causing them to abide without destruction.
Why did the World-Honored One only say that sentient beings abide through food?
What are the seven?ğŸ”½First, arising is the cause for the abiding of conditioned forces.
Because conditioned forces only abide after arising.
There is no abiding without arising.
Second, the life faculty.
Third, food.
Fourth, the power of the mind.
By their power, the life-force of beings increases.
Either abiding for one kalpa or abiding for the remainder of a kalpa.
Fifth, the combination of causes and conditions.
This is the cause for the abiding of conditioned forces.
That is to say, good, evil, and indeterminate dharmas.
As long as the causes and conditions have not yet dissipated.
For that long, the continuity abides without interruption.
Sixth, by means of good, evil, and indeterminate attention, one activates past karma.
It can draw in conditioned forces, causing them to abide without cessation.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Namely, the external parts are produced by shared and unshared karma.
Seventh, there is no obstruction.
This is the cause for the abiding of all activities.
By this, when all activities are born, there is the cause of non-obstruction.
After all activities are born, they abide in a similar continuity.
Far removed from the causes of opposition and destruction.
If it were not so, then it would be destroyed.
Answer: Although all activities are able to abide by these seven kinds of causes and conditions,
these four foods are the causes for the abiding of all activities for the most part.
By various means, they are able to cause the continuity of all activities to abide.
Moreover, these foods are able to cause the continuity of sentient beings to abide.
Easy to grasp and easy to enter.
Even foolish people and infants are able to follow and understand.
Not so for other dharmas.
Moreover, these foods are able to cause the weakened faculties and primary elements to all increase and benefit.
Moreover, they are able to cause illnesses to be cured.
Not so for other dharmas.
Moreover, there are long-lived sentient beings.
If they do not obtain food, they die prematurely.
Moreover, these foods make it easy to enter the path.
One is able to cultivate the four kinds of mindfulness, such as mindfulness of the body.
Because all sentient beings abide by means of food.
Therefore, for these five reasons,
the World-Honored One only says that all sentient beings abide by means of food.
Why is it also said that conditioned phenomena abide by relying on the life faculty?
There are places where there is never a lack of food and drink.
There is no difficulty in seeking food and drink.
In those places, one abides only by the power of the life faculty.
One abides for the duration of one's lifespan as it was received.
Therefore, the World-Honored One, relying on those places, says that conditioned phenomena abide due to the life faculty.
Next, in this context, material food should be said to be included in the realms of smell, taste, and touch.
Why is it so?
Because if smell, taste, and touch are properly digested, they can nourish.
When it is not properly digested, it becomes a loss.
Form and other dharmas do not have growth, loss, or digestion.
Therefore, they are said not to be the nature of material food.
If a certain material object, when swallowed,
causes the mind to rejoice and the faculties to be delighted,
at that time it is not called material food.
It is only called contact food.
If, after being consumed, it is peacefully digested,
and increases joy and pleasure,
when it is being digested, it is called material food.
If there is digestion that cannot nourish the faculties and bring peace and joy,
even though it is digested, it is not called material food.
If a certain material object, when swallowed,
does not give rise to joy and cannot cause the faculties to be delighted,
at that time it is not called food at all.
Later, when it is peacefully digested and increases peace and joy,
at that time it is called material food.
If there is digestion that does not increase peace and joy,
even though it is digested, it is still not called food.
Question: If there is a substance that is also food,
if it is food, is it also a substance?
Answer: As appropriate, four sentences should be made.
There may be a substance that is not food.
It refers to substances that cannot nourish the faculties and the great elements.
There may be food that is not a substance.
It refers to contact, intention, and consciousness.
It can cause the faculties and the great elements to grow.
There may be food that is also a substance.
It refers to substances that can cause the faculties and the great elements to grow.
There may be neither a substance nor food.
It refers to contact, intention, and consciousness.
It cannot cause the faculties and the great elements to grow.
In this way, the remaining contacts up to consciousness,
according to what is appropriate, all make four sentences.
Next, if there are dharmas with retribution,ğŸ”½if they are dharmas with retribution,
if they are dharmas born from retribution,
they should all be understood.
In brief, there are dharmas with retribution.
It refers to the contaminants and that which is contaminated.
They must have power, not be damaged, and not be exhausted in one's experience.
One should know that this is called the dharmas with retribution.
Among the contaminants, the unwholesome ones are called powerful.
The obscured indeterminate ones are called powerless.
Among the contaminated ones, the wholesome and unwholesome ones are called powerful.
The rest are called powerless.
If the contaminants and contaminated dharmas are severed by the paths of detachment from the world and beyond,
They are called damaged.
The opposite of this is called undamaged.
If in the past, the retribution for their results has already matured,
They are called exhausted in one's experience.
Because their retribution has already passed, there is nothing more.
If in the future, they will give rise to retribution,
If in the present, the retribution for their results is right before one,
They are called not exhausted in one's experience.
By this distinction, the contaminants and contaminated dharmas, as appropriate,
If they are wholesome or unwholesome and have not yet been eliminated by antidotes,
their karmic retribution has not yet matured.
This is called having karmic retribution.ğŸ”½If they are pure, indeterminate, or contaminated,
if they are wholesome or unwholesome and contaminated, and have been eliminated,
if their karmic retribution has already matured,
this is called having no karmic retribution.
Also, the final thought at the moment of death is a karmic retribution.
If the mind of uninterrupted continuity at the time of rebirth also has karmic retribution,
from then on all minds that naturally abide have karmic retribution.
Except for wholesome and defiled [minds],
and except for the effortful indeterminate mind,
the remaining are all called naturally abiding minds.
If the mind is free from desire and still continues to function,
except for the wholesome [minds] of the lower stages and the effortful indeterminate mind,
one should know that this mind also has karmic retribution.ğŸ”½Moreover, this karmic retribution
should be said to be only unobstructed and indeterminate in all cases.
If it arises from the seeds of retribution,
excluding those dharmas that have already been cut off or not yet obtained,
the remaining dharmas born from their own seeds as causes,
whether wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate,
all should be known as dharmas born of retribution.
Furthermore, the final mind of death in all realms,
and the mind of the first and second moments of continuity,
in the three realms should be known as only the feeling of neither-suffering-nor-happiness.
Except for the mind of the first moment of continuity,
it should be known that this feeling is included in retribution in all realms.
The remaining feelings of suffering and happiness should be known as born of retribution.
According to the seeds included in retribution,
following this cause and taking it as the causal condition,
from retribution, beings are born in the hells.
Immediately after retribution, there is that born of retribution.
The continuity of suffering and sorrow is like being born in the hells. In this way,
if born in a part of the hungry ghosts and animals,
One should know it is also like this.ğŸ”½If one is born among humans or in the desire realm heavens,
all sentient beings
have no definite ripening.
Sometimes there is suffering and sorrow,
sometimes there is joy and happiness,
sometimes there is only the arising of a continuous stream of neither-suffering-nor-happiness.
If one is born in the first or second concentration,
the ripening is only a continuous stream of the ripening-born joy.
If one is born in the third concentration,
it is only a continuous stream of the ripening-born happiness.
If one is born in the fourth concentration and above,
there is only the ripening-born neither-suffering-nor-happiness.
Therefore one should know that in those realms, this very feeling is called ripening-born, because it is embraced by vast joy and happiness.
When the good karma that is neither-suffering-nor-happiness is actually present,
it is also called desirable ripening.
The opposite of this should be known as undesirable ripening.
Next, the ripening-born, unrestrained, indeterminate fruit obtained from white-white ripening karma,
It is only pleasant feeling.
Because it is accompanied by the seeds.
It should be understood that it is only pleasant and agreeable.
Black-black-retribution karma should be understood as the opposite of this.
Black-and-white-retribution karma.
Because it is accompanied by the seeds of both kinds.
The retribution fruit that is obtained should be understood as also having two kinds of retribution-born feelings.
Moreover, black-and-white karma is established according to the differences in the class of beings.
That is to say, in this case, black and white both exist.
In this very place, karma is generally established as black-and-white.
Moreover, it is established according to the differences in the matter.
That is to say, it is like a certain person who, with regard to a certain matter, at a certain time gives rise to a mind of benefit that appears before him.
With regard to this very matter, at another time a mind of no benefit appears before him.
Or, having taken another's possessions, he practices giving.
In this way, it should be understood that it is established according to the differences in the matter.
Moreover, this black-and-white karma is established according to its own nature.
It is like someone who wishes to benefit someone in one way,
but due to other circumstances, he ends up harming them.
For example, someone may give rise to thoughts accompanied by anger towards a very violent and evil person,
and not be happy with their evil deeds.
You should know that these thoughts, because they are accompanied by anger,
fall into the black category.
Because they are not happy with the evil deeds,
they fall into the white category.
Therefore, this karma is said to be black and white.
The other types are also like this.
All dharmas whose seeds have not yet been destroyed,
all these dharmas are called dharmas with causes due to the cause of production that gives rise to them.
Moreover, the past karma and afflictions
in the three realms that have already produced their ripened results,
these ripened results are called dharmas with causes due to the cause of attraction by karma and afflictions.
Moreover, due to the cause of attraction that is present in the three realms,
Among the born and womb-born,
it should be known that this is also called the dharmas with causes.ğŸ”½Because of the combination of moisture, the moisture-born are born.
Because of the egg-shell, the egg-born are born.
It should be known that it is also like this.
Moreover, the group of six consciousnesses, from the eye and form up to the mind and dharmas,
are the dominant conditions and the co-operating causes,
therefore they are called the dharmas with causes.
Moreover, the co-arisen mind and mental factors,
mutually become the co-operating causes,
therefore they are called the dharmas with causes.
Moreover, the unwholesome dharmas, by associating with bad friends, hearing wrong teachings, and improper contemplation,
are the projecting causes,
therefore they are called the dharmas with causes.
It should be known that the opposite of these three projecting causes,
all wholesome dharmas are called the dharmas with causes.
Moreover, the defiled abiding gives rise to wrong effort,
without result, and the suffering of exertion arises.
They are called the dharmas with causes because of the projecting causes.
Moreover, the undefiled abiding gives rise to right effort,
There are results, and the joy and pleasure of exertion arise.
They are called dharmas with causes because of the cause of attraction.
Moreover, the mundane path leads to detachment.
And it can attract the meditative absorptions and formless attainments.
They are called dharmas with causes because of the cause of attraction.
Moreover, in the present life, the meditative absorptions and formless attainments serve as supports.
According to their respective capacities, one is reborn in the higher realms.
They are called dharmas with causes because of the cause of attraction.
Moreover, the mundane dharmas attract the supramundane dharmas.
They are called dharmas with causes because of the cause of attraction.
Moreover, the supramundane dharmas are included in the noble path and can realize nirvana.
The realization of nirvana is because of the cause of attraction.
It is called a dharma with causes.
Because of these aforementioned characteristics,
it should be known that the establishment of dharmas with causes is made.
Next, in this context, the dharmas of the generative productive cause,
because of their respective individual outflow effects,
are called dharmas with results.
If there are karmic actions and afflictions that lead to future existences,
they are called dharmas with results due to the ripening result of each.
If there are three conditions present,
if there is a present combination of moisture,
if there is an egg or womb,
if there is eye and form, etc.,
if there are minds and mental factors that arise together with them,
if there is association with bad friends, etc.,
if there is association with good friends, etc.,
all of these are called dharmas with results due to the dominant result of each.
If in the present life one dwells in defilement and gives rise to wrong effort,
one gives rise to worry and suffering due to fruitless exertion.
If in the present life one dwells without defilement and gives rise to right effort,
one gives rise to joy and pleasure due to fruitful exertion.
All of these are called dharmas with results due to the human effort result of each.
If one cultivates the path of detachment from desire for the worldly realms,
it is called a dharma with results due to the dominant result of separation.
Are called dharmas with results.ğŸ”½And can also lead to the supramundane path.
And can realize the supramundane noble path of nirvana.
By the dominant result of being free from bonds,
Are called dharmas with results.
That is, by the result of being ultimately free from bonds,
Are called dharmas with results.
If the mundane path is not by the result of being ultimately free from bonds,
Are called dharmas with results.
This should be known as the difference between the two paths.
By these characteristics that have been explained,
It should be known that the characteristics of establishing dharmas with results are distinguished.
That is, according to what is appropriate,
Establish the outflow result.ğŸ”½If the result of ripening,ğŸ”½If the dominant result,
If the result of human effort,
If the result of being free from bonds.
It should be known that the establishment of dharmas without causes and dharmas without results is contrary to this.
Next, the dharmas of dependent origination
Are those that are without a master, without a creator.
As has been extensively distinguished in the skillful means of dependent origination in the discernment of the mental realm above.
Moreover, it should be known that the establishment of the distinctions of internal dharmas is due to five causes in brief.
Because of these causes, they are called internal.
What are the five?
Namely, because of designation.
Because of false grasping.
Because of predominance.
Because of the seeds that are included.
Because of the matter.
If in a certain place, one designates and establishes this kind of category,
namely, establishing it as a self or establishing it as a sentient being,
that is called by such a name, born in such a class,
and so on up to having such a lifespan.
This is called the internal dharmas because of designation.
If in a certain place, one falsely gives rise to this kind of attachment and grasping,
namely, reckoning it as a self or giving rise to the conceit of self,
this is called the internal dharmas because of false grasping.
If because of this dharma's predominant power,
the distinctions of external form, sound, etc. arise as what is to be experienced,
This is called internal dharmas in terms of predominance.
If they can embrace the seeds of good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas,
this is called internal dharmas in terms of embracing seeds.
If the five kinds of pure form, mind, thought, and consciousness,
this is called internal dharmas in terms of function.
There are also other dharmas that are established as internal by means of provisional names.
Why is it so?
Because they are also called internal because they are included in the internal sense bases.
Moreover, it should be known that the five aggregates are included in form.
Why is it so?
Because they can be obtained through growth in various places.
When touched by a lump of mud and so forth, they are immediately destroyed.
Therefore, the form aggregate is called form.
The remaining four aggregates are established by the power of various names.
By relying on various names,
they mostly flow and move towards those various objects.
Therefore, these four formless aggregates are called names.
Furthermore, the distinction of the dharmas that are grasped is established in brief by five aspects.
What are the five?
First, only form is called grasping.
It should be known that these words exclude the mind and mental factors, etc.
Because they are not grasped.
Moreover, among the forms, the internal faculties,
and what is dependent on the faculties is called grasping.
It should be known that these words exclude the external forms that are not dependent on the faculties.
Because they are not grasped.
Moreover, the mind and mental factors that are maintained and not abandoned are called grasping.
It should be known that these words exclude the hair, body hair, nails, etc. that are dependent on the faculties,
and exclude the internal body after death.
Because they are not grasped.
Moreover, the form that is grasped is transformed by four causes and conditions, therefore
it is called grasping.
What are the four?ğŸ”½First, because it is oppressed by external forms,
second, because it is equally induced by the internal realms that are in opposition,
Third, because of the frequent occurrence of various afflictions such as greed and hatred.
Fourth, because of the careful consideration of the object.ğŸ”½That is to say, because of external forms that can harm,
when they directly afflict the appropriated form,
one then gives rise to suffering, compassion, and distress.
If there is external form that can benefit,
when it directly contacts the appropriated form,
one then gives rise to pleasure, peace, and benefit.
If there is mutual opposition among the internal elements,
one then gives rise to suffering and distress.
If they are equal, then there is the embrace of blissful acceptance.
Moreover, if one is afflicted by afflictions such as greed,
one then gives rise to suffering, anger, and burning.
Moreover, because of the careful consideration of the object,
or because of the careful consideration of the object,
one then gives rise to the embrace of lightness, peace, joy, and pleasure.
Moreover, because of harm or benefit,
it is called change.
In this way, whether it is form, the internal, or the mind and mental factors, one should not abandon their support.
If it is so conditioned to become transformed,
this is called the distinction of the dharmas that are grasped.
The opposite of this should be known as the dharmas that are not grasped.
Furthermore, if the four great elements and their derivatives,
it should be known that only these are called the dharmas with form.
Question: Just as the four great elements are born from their own seeds,
so are the derivatives.
Why is it said that the derivatives are formed by the great elements?
Answer: If there are seeds of the great elements in the sense faculties and the mind,
then there are seeds of the derivatives that follow.
When the seeds of the great elements are able to produce results,
at that time they are definitely able to follow and the seeds of the derivatives will also produce their own results.
Therefore it is said that the derivatives are formed by the great elements.
The seeds of the great elements that follow the sense faculties with form are called having a location.
The seeds of the great elements that follow the sense faculties without form are called having no location.
Moreover, the great elements are roughly of two kinds.
The first is only included in the realms.
The second is able to perform its own function.
As for being only included in the realms,
it refers to the seeds of the great elements.
As for being able to perform its own function,
it refers to the great elements that arise from their own seeds.
Moreover, the great elements and the derivative form
exist simultaneously and are mutually inseparable.
Because they are formed by their respective types of causes,
like a single lump of dough that penetrates everywhere by mutually interpenetrating.
It is not like a heap of flour, rice, or jewels.
Moreover, in a mass of form that is exclusively solid,
only the earth element is able to perform its function.
If in the desire realm there is also the function of the form, smell, and taste realms,
in the form realm there is only the function of the form realm.
The other water, fire, wind, and sound realms
only have seeds that follow along with them.
They must wait for other conditions before they can perform their function.
In this way, in the conceptual masses of water, fire, and wind,
The order is also the same as appropriate.
In the internal collection of form, all the activities of the elements such as earth are fully present.
Namely, the various distinctions such as hair, body hair, and so forth.
As extensively explained in the sutras.
One should know that externally, there are separate collections of earth and so forth.
If they encounter such and such distinctions in conditions,
They will then be able to act as the causes for the arising of such and such resultant dharmas.
For example, like skillfully drilling dry wood and immediately producing fire.
Also, like white copper, lead, tin, gold, silver, and so forth melting and immediately flowing.
Furthermore, as explained in the stage associated with the five sense consciousnesses, the nature of roughness and smoothness, etc. that are included in the sphere of touch,
One should know are all distinctions of the great elements.
According to the various categories of the great elements, in this way, distinctions in states occur.
As appropriate, regarding the four great elements,
The natures of roughness, smoothness, etc. are provisionally established.
Therefore, one should know they all exist as provisional designations.
Question: As the World-Honored One said, contact is an external sense base, either the four great elements or what is derived from the four great elements, having form, invisible, and impinging.
What is the hidden meaning?
Answer: It should be known that these great elements can produce two kinds of derivative form.
First, distinctions within their own category;
second, distinctions in different categories.
As for derivative form with distinctions within its own category,
it refers to the rough, smooth, etc. produced by the great elements.
Due to such causes and such conditions,
these great elements each give rise to distinctions and transformations.
In them, rough, smooth, etc. are provisionally established as various distinctions.
As for derivative form with distinctions in different categories,
it refers to the five internal sense bases of eye, ear, etc., the four external sense bases of form, etc., and one part of the sense base of mental objects.
Excluding only the sense base of touch.
The World-Honored One, based on the derivative form with distinctions within its own category,
made the following statement:
What is derived from the four great elements.
Question: The World-Honored One spoke of form that is invisible and impinging.
What should be said about the great elements and derivatives?
Answer: If in that concentration mind one contemplates the form dharmas of the desire realm,
the images arise.
It should be said that they are derived from the great elements of the desire realm.
If in that concentration mind one contemplates the form dharmas of the form realm,
the images arise.
It should be said that they are derived from the great elements of the form realm.
Regarding these great elements and derivative form dharmas,
the remaining texts for definitive analysis do not appear again.
Next, what are the dharmas that exist?
It is said that all worldly dharmas are called dharmas that exist.
Question: The worldly good dharmas of arhats and others,
because they are worldly, are then included.
For what reason are they called uncontaminated?
Answer: Because they fall into the three existences, they are called included.
Because they are eternally liberated from the bonds and latent tendencies of the contaminations, they are called uncontaminated.
Question: As the World-Honored One said, what are the contaminated dharmas?
They are the worldly mind, worldly dharmas, and worldly mental consciousness.
What is the hidden meaning of this?
The World-Honored One, based on the uninterrupted, should-be-interrupted worldly mind, dharma, and mental consciousness,
spoke in this way.
Here, the World-Honored One spoke of many kinds of existence,
namely, existence in the desire realm, existence in the form realm, and existence in the formless realm.
Their extensive establishment is like what can be known through the wisdom of hearing and the teachings of the Buddha.
All other dharmas.
It should be known that nirvana is the unsurpassed dharma due to five reasons.
What are the five?
First, because of the cessation of the truth of accumulation.
Second, because of the cessation of the truth of suffering.
Third, because of being free from fear, calamity, and great peace.
Fourth, because it is the basis for abiding in the unsurpassed bliss of the present world.
That is, because it is the abode of signlessness.
Fifth, because it is eternally abiding, ultimately peaceful, blissful, and not deceptive.
Such five reasons cannot be found in any other place.
Only in nirvana can they all be found.
Therefore, nirvana is called the unsurpassed dharma.
Next, what is the dharma that should be cultivated?
It refers to all wholesome conditioned dharmas.
Herein, one should know that there are four kinds of cultivation in brief.
First, cultivation of attainment;
second, cultivation of practice;
third, cultivation of removal;
fourth, cultivation of antidotes.
Herein, in order to generate wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen, one cultivates with attention.
This is called cultivation of attainment.
Wholesome dharmas that have already arisen, one causes them to abide without forgetting, and so on at length.
This is called cultivation of practice.
Unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen, in order to eliminate them, one cultivates with attention.
This is called cultivation of removal.
Unwholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen, in order to prevent their arising,
one cultivates with attention in the various antidotal approaches such as disgust.
This is called cultivation of antidotes.
Herein, one should know that from the attention of discerning characteristics up to the attention of resolve,
this is called cultivation of antidotes through disgust.
From the attention of separation up to the attention of final expedient means,
this is called cultivation of antidotes through elimination.
The attention of the fruit of final expedient means,
this is called cultivation of antidotes through upholding.
From here on, all these seven kinds of attention
fall into the superior stages and are included in the higher stages.
It should be known that all of them are called the cultivation of remote separation.
These four kinds of cultivation are all collectively called the two kinds of cultivation.
Namely, the cultivation of guarding and upholding,
and the cultivation of contemplating with thought.
Among them, cultivating the body is called the cultivation of guarding,
cultivating precepts is called the cultivation of upholding.
If cultivating with attention in the stage of meditation,
if cultivating with attention in the stage of the wisdom of the truths,
it is collectively called the cultivation of contemplating with thought.
Among them, the initial cultivation with attention is called the cultivation of the mind,
the second cultivation with attention is called the cultivation of wisdom.
Next, what are past dharmas?
It is said: causes have already been exhausted,
the intrinsic nature has already ceased,
without interval, serving as conditions for the arising of other dharmas.
Except for the imprints of the last mind and mental factors of an arhat,
although they have already ceased, passing through a hundred thousand kalpas,ğŸ”½...
Still, it can cause the ripening of pleasant or unpleasant karmic results.
Like the various past events that are experienced,
Some can only give rise to memories,
While others do not give rise to memories.
They are only manifested by cessation and have no function.
This is called the distinction of past dharmas.
These past dharmas should be known to be established in terms of their distinctions by five characteristics.
What are the five?
It means that there are dharmas that are past in a moment.ğŸ”½It means that in every moment of conditioned forces,
All conditioned forces after that moment,
Again, there are dharmas that are past in death.
It means that sentient beings die from the various groups of sentient beings,
Extending to the time of death and action.
Again, there are dharmas that are past in the destruction of the eon.
It means that the world system is included,
Destroyed by the calamities of fire and so forth.
Again, there are dharmas that are past in regression.
It refers to when someone, in the midst of the wholesome qualities and blissful abodes they have already attained,
retreats and loses them.
Moreover, there are dharmas that are completely extinguished in the past.
It refers to the complete extinction in the nirvÄá¹‡a realm with remainder and without remainder.
Next, what are future dharmas?
It refers to those whose causes have not yet been received and whose intrinsic nature has not yet been received.
Awaiting conditions, they will arise in the future, will be produced in the future, and will manifest in the future.
Either they will arise soon in the future or they will arise far in the future.
They are also established by five aspects.
It refers to momentary future,
future of one birth,ğŸ”½future of the eon of formation,
future of present activity,
and future of what should be attained.
Next, what are present dharmas?
It refers to those whose causes have already been received and used, whose intrinsic nature has been received and used but not yet exhausted,
and which will definitely perish after a moment. They are manifested by all defilements,
and by a part of purity.
They are also established by five aspects.
It refers to momentary present,
One life in the present.ğŸ”½The present of the eon of formation.
The present of present activity.
The present of the final [moment].
Refers to the final mind and mental factors of an arhat, and so on.
Next, what are the dharmas bound to the desire realm?
It means if one is born in the desire realm,
and has not yet abandoned the desires of the desire realm,
and the mind is not in concentration.
In this state, all dharmas,ğŸ”½whether obtained through birth or through attention,
have been practiced, are being practiced, or will be practiced.
This is called the dharmas bound to the desire realm.
Next, what are the dharmas bound to the form realm?
It means being born in the desire realm, able to directly realize and enter
any one of the meditative absorptions, having already abandoned the desires of the desire realm,
but not yet abandoned the desires of the form realm,
not yet initiated the preparatory efforts for the higher [realms],
or having arisen from that meditative absorption,
all the worldly mental dharmas
that have been practiced, are being practiced, or will be practiced due to attention,
are called the dharmas bound to the form realm.
Or being born in the form realm, not yet having abandoned the desires of that [realm],
Not yet engaged in the preparatory stages.
Either due to birth or intention.
All worldly dharmas that have been practiced, are being practiced, or will be practiced.
Such are also called dharmas bound to the form realm.
As with dharmas bound to the form realm, so should one understand dharmas bound to the formless realm accordingly.
Next, what are wholesome dharmas?
In brief,
all wholesome dharmas are called wholesome for two reasons.
Namely, their intrinsic nature is non-inverted,
and they are also able to counteract inverted dharmas.
And because they are peaceful and secure.
Why is this?
All wholesome dharmas, by their intrinsic nature, are non-inverted and operate on their objects.
And they are also able to counteract inverted defiled dharmas that operate on their objects.
They are able to lead to good destinies and realize nirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore they are called peaceful and secure.
One should understand that unwholesome [dharmas] are the opposite of this for two reasons,
namely because their intrinsic nature is inverted and they are not peaceful and secure.
Neutral dharmas are not inverted by nature,
It also cannot cure inverted dharmas.
Its nature is neither peaceful nor not peaceful.
Moreover, by means of five aspects, one should understand the establishment of the distinctions of wholesome dharmas.
First, because it attracts lovable fruits in the future.
Second, because it is the antidote to defilements.
That is to say, such things as impurity can cure greed, etc.,
up to the eightfold noble path, which is the antidote to all defiled dharmas.
Third, because it manifests the cessation of defilements.
That is to say, nirvana.
Fourth, because it manifests the abode of purity.
That is to say, the pleasant abiding in the present life of the holy ones who have already become free from desire.
Fifth, because it manifests the benefit of sentient beings.
That is to say, those who have already become free from desire.
Out of compassion for others, the various wholesome activities for benefiting others of Å›rÄvakas, bodhisattvas, and tathÄgatas.
Moreover, the establishment of distinctions of unwholesome dharmas is by means of five aspects.
One should understand its characteristics as being the opposite of the above.
That is to say, because it attracts unlovable fruits in the future.
Because it is what is to be countered by the antidote to defilements.
Because it is manifested by defilement and non-cessation.
Because it is manifested by the abode of defilement and affliction.
Because it is manifested by the harm done to others.
There are five reasons why wholesome dharmas are powerful.
What are the five?
First, due to practice.
Second, due to past habituation.
Third, due to embracing superior qualities.
Fourth, due to the field and matter.
Fifth, due to the intrinsic nature.
It means that wholesome dharmas are created by uninterrupted practice and earnest practice.
If they are created by immeasurable categories.
It means either one does them oneself.
Or in this case, one encourages others to do them.
With immeasurable methods, one rejoices and praises them.
Seeing those of the same Dharma, one deeply rejoices in one's heart.
One should know that this is called the power of wholesome dharmas due to practice.
Moreover, wholesome dharmas that were cultivated, practiced, and greatly cultivated in other lives.
For this reason, in this life,
By nature, one's mind is able to enter into wholesome dharmas.
Abiding in opposition to all unwholesome [actions].
One should know that this is called the strength of wholesome dharmas due to past habituation.
Moreover, wholesome dharmas are included in the lower stages.
By those who are detached from the mundane world and those who have seen the traces of the sages.
If one deeply aspires for liberation or supreme perfect enlightenment.
Free from the various views and tendencies.
One should know that this is called the strength of wholesome dharmas due to embracing superior merits.
Moreover, wholesome dharmas arise from making excellent offerings to the great field of blessings.
One should know that this is called the strength of wholesome dharmas due to the field, matter, and place.
Moreover, if wholesome dharmas are accomplished through giving.
Their intrinsic nature is inferior in terms of precepts and cultivation.
If they are accomplished through precepts.
Their intrinsic nature is superior in terms of what is accomplished through giving.
Their intrinsic nature is inferior in terms of what is accomplished through cultivation.
If wholesome dharmas are accomplished through cultivation.
Their intrinsic nature is superior in terms of giving and precepts.
One should know that this is called the strong flourishing of good dharmas due to their own nature.
The opposite of this is due to five causes.
One should know that this is called the strong flourishing of unwholesomeness.
Moreover, the distinction of indeterminate dharmas is established by five aspects.
What are the five?
First, indeterminate dharmas born of retribution;
second, indeterminate dharmas of deportment;
third, indeterminate dharmas of craftsmanship;
fourth, indeterminate dharmas of transformation;
fifth, indeterminate dharmas by nature.
Among them, indeterminate dharmas by nature refer to the material sense faculties.
Those that are nourished and the external material sense bases, etc., that are not included in retribution, etc.
Except for the wholesome and defiled form sense bases and sound sense bases.
Next, what are the dharmas of training?
It refers to the individual who is a stream-enterer, once-returner, or non-returner in training.
If they are conditioned dharmas that transcend the world,
or wholesome dharmas of the world,
these are called dharmas of training.
Why is it so?
Relying on these dharmas, from time to time...
Because they diligently cultivate and study the superior precepts, superior concentration, and superior wisdom.
What are the unlearned dharmas?
It is said that the arhats have already exhausted all defilements.ğŸ”½If it is a supramundane conditioned dharma,
Or if it is a mundane wholesome dharma,
This is called the unlearned dharma.
What are the dharmas that are neither learned nor unlearned? It is said that excluding the previously mentioned learned and unlearned dharmas,
The remaining dharmas of the stream-enterers up to the arhats,
If they fall into the continuum of all ordinary beings,
Or if they are the dharmas that arise due to their dominance,
One should know that these are called the dharmas that are neither learned nor unlearned.
Furthermore, what are the dharmas that are eliminated by the path of seeing?
It is said that the five views such as the view of the aggregates,
And the greed, hatred, and pride that arise based on those views,
If they are associated with ignorance,
Or if it is the ignorance that is not common regarding the truths,
The doubts and so forth regarding the truths,
And the karma that leads to all evil destinies, etc.,
These are called the dharmas that are eliminated by the path of seeing.
What are the dharmas to be eliminated by the path of cultivation?
They are all wholesome contaminated dharmas.
All unobstructed indeterminate dharmas.
Except for the defiled dharmas mentioned above.
The remaining defiled dharmas.
These are called the dharmas to be eliminated by the path of cultivation.
What are the dharmas that are not to be eliminated?
They are all supramundane dharmas of those still learning.
All dharmas in the continuum of those who have attained arhatship.
Among them, supramundane dharmas are not to be eliminated because they are pure by nature at all times.
The remaining mundane dharmas are not to be eliminated because they have already been eliminated.
Next, what are the profound and difficult-to-see dharmas?
They are all dharmas.
It should be known that they are all profound and difficult to see.
Why is this?
The foremost profound and difficult-to-see dharmağŸ”½Is that which transcends all conceptual proliferation by nature and surpasses the realm of language.
The nature of all dharmas transcends conceptual proliferation and surpasses the realm of language.
However, it is based on language.
only then can it be grasped, observed, and cognized.
Therefore, one should know that all dharmas are very profound and difficult to see.
Dharmas without seeing.ğŸ”½Dharmas with resistance and without resistance.ğŸ”½Dharmas with outflows and without outflows.
Dharmas with disputes and without disputes.
Dharmas with defilements and without defilements.
Dharmas based on indulgence and based on renunciation.
Dharmas that fall and do not fall into the mundane and supramundane.
Dharmas with form and without form.
Dharmas that are to be known, cognized, and perceived.
Dharmas that are upheld.
Dharmas with retribution and without retribution.
Dharmas with causes and without causes.
Dharmas with effects and without effects.
Dharmas that arise from conditions, internal dharmas.
Dharmas that are included in name and form.
Dharmas that are appropriated and not appropriated.
Dharmas that are created by the great elements and not created by the great elements.
Dharmas that exist and do not exist.
Dharmas that should be cultivated.
Dharmas that are superior and unsurpassed.
Dharmas of the past, present, and future.
Dharmas bound to the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm.
wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate dharmas.
dharmas of training, post-training, and neither training nor post-training.
dharmas eliminated by the path of seeing, eliminated by the path of cultivation, and not eliminated.
dharmas that are profound and difficult to see.
If there are those who skillfully contemplate what should be contemplated,
they should diligently and skillfully contemplate and discern these dharmas in accordance with the principles.
